Legal_Issue: Whether Nidek's EC-5000 apparatus infringes VISX's patents for corneal surgery devices
Evidence_Assessment: Comparison of EC-5000 features with patent claims; technical analysis of ablation method and device components
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when a device falls within the scope of a patent's claims; claim construction is a legal matter, infringement is a mixed question of fact and law
Standard_of_Review: De novo for claim construction; clear error standard for factual findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of three Canadian patents related to ophthalmological surgery devices
Key_Evidence_Considered: Structure and function of EC-5000; absence of topography-display unit; use of iris diaphragm and variable slit instead of beam shaping/focusing
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law framework for infringement and claim interpretation
Legal_Rule_Source: Case law on patent infringement and claim construction
Defendant_Response: EC-5000 does not meet the claimed elements of VISX's patents
Evidence_Type: Technical specifications, patent claims, device functionality analysis
Outcome: No liability; patents valid but not infringed
Remedy_Sought: Injunction, damages, or other relief for infringement
Authority: Court with jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes
Legal_Provision_Cited: Three Canadian patents related to corneal surgery devices
Governing_Rule: Patent claims define the scope of protection; infringement requires falling within that scope
